comments.value: Create a Google Video sitemap

subject: Generation of Video XML Google sitemap
description: Create a Google Video sitemap

comments.value:
General sitemap, a couple things we need to deal with, which make it tricker than just looking though all the page son the site and outputting an XML file.

a) Excluding pages that are in the CMS but aren't normally navigable to. As you say everything that does not have 'hide from navigation' should appear, but it's not quite as simple as we do have pages that are excluded by section for example signup pages and test directories.

Probably the best thing here is for us to create the site map and then have a run though it and see if we can spot any pages that shouldn't be in it.

b) Splitting the files out into multiple files to get round the Google limit of 5000 pages, not an issue per sea but need to do a few queries to work out who to split the site up , probably best if we separate out the sections with large amounts of content, ie. news, images, suppliers and then leave another file with just standard 'content' pages.

Will run some counts of the top sections to work out where to split.

c) Updates, once again not an issue per sea. but we've been discussing internally how best to handle this in the CMS as generating a site map for the whole site each day (or more frequently) is fairly processor heavy.

We can start with a new sitemap generated at say 2am each night.

d) "Virtual hub pages" this is a very interesting one, especially as we're about to relaunch the News section using this format/method. By "Virtual hub pages" I mean hub pages (ie. "Culture News") that don't actually exist in he CMS but are instead created 'on the fly' via a url such as "london2012.com/news?tag=culture" or london2012.com/photos?tag=culture". Currently Google will find these pages via it's crawler, so there is no issue. But once we switch to using a sitemap there seems to be consensus (via a bit of googling) that results from crawling can drop once you are actively serving a site map (I expect Larry Page n isn't even sure and that half of this stuff is old wives tales / speculation).

I think Danny/Kieran have already proposed some work/costs as an extension to the SEO work (copying Danny/Kieran in on this response) to store these urls in the CMS, so that you could link to /news/culture in the CMS but that would actually be mapped to /news?tag=culture. If we did this then we'd have a list of all those 'psudo hub pages' and could export them in the sitemap.

In the immediate term, I assume we'll just have to live without them and hope Google doesn't start to drop the hub pages for given topics (ie. Culture News). In the medium term, if we haven't completed the work above, I guess we could hardcode a sitemap of urls for the key 'pseudo hub pages'.

subject: Generation of General XML Google sitemap (not incl news/video/photos - these have separate tickets)

comments.value:
From: Morag Reavley <Morag.Reavley@london2012.com>

Hello

Caught up with colleagues on this.

We would like to be able to continue featuring blog commenting when
password support is switched off.

What are the ramifications of the following solution:

1. A user who wants to comment has to fill in Screen name, email
address and comment fields, plus complete a captcha.

2. Comments go into the comment moderation functionality as presently
i.e. all comments are pre-moderated.

Do you think this would wash from a) a technical perspective b) a
security perspective (is this method inherently less secure than the
current approach)?
Initial estimate: 5+ days. Awaiting go ahead.
Just approved by Morag. Needed in advance of the switchover.
Yes, you can do this ahead of switch to eDialog.

subject: Registration workflow, blog commenting and switch to e-dialog

Duncan

The promo link should now open in the same window on the venue pages

The venue promos are actually different from the normal promos hence the different behaviour.

External text links in copy will however still have an external site icon and open in an external window unless they contain www.london2012.com, we need to make a low level change to rectify this behaviour (it's not simply a config file).

Jamie

Thanks

Let me know if and when you can make this low level change

Thanks

Duncan

Kieran

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Aaron Shone <Aaron.Shone@london2012.com>
Date: 7 June 2011 19:13
Subject: forthcomming CR raised
To: Danny Sofer <danny@kitsite.com>


Danny, as discussed, I have raised a CR to request the changes to the
Kitsite CMS. This is a heads up only, all changes should be managed by
Russ Ede as the operations manager...



Kitsite are requested to implement the following pre-agreed changes to
the CMS, following discussions as to appropriate remedial action.



1) Cross Site Request forgery: Functions that perform sensitive
actions should send the user a token as a hidden input field which is
unique to the users session. The token should be submitted with the
form and validated against the users session. Only requests that
induce a change in the application need to be subject to these
controls; for example, functions that update or delete data.



2) Information disclosure: Modify the web server configuration to
return a custom error page (specifically
https://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/servlet/upload and other referenced in
pen test report)

fix dev server to prohibit directory listings (given examples include
https://dev.kitsite.com/kit/admin/ and
https://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/admin/ but should be fixed at the
server configuration level to encompass the whole site



3) File upload abuse: remove php as an allowed type to be uploaded,
and confirm that this does not affect existing assets.



4) Session compromise : Ensure that the ‘HttpOnly’ and ‘Secure’ flags
are set on the JSESSIONID cookie.



5) disable HTTP trace method



Further to our meeting, can you provide a list of the current users,
roles  and level of access (constraints) to the LOCOG CMS, so we can
conduct a user access review and perhaps tweak users access privileges
to that which allows them to do their jobs and nothing more?



Also, could you investigate how difficult it would be to implement a
suit of password controls including complexity, length, age etc, or
alternatively, 2 factor authentication, to protect privileged
(publisher) access to the site?



Many thanks,



Aaron



Aaron Shone

IT Security Architect - Technology

comments.value:
Okay, Olympic tickets are out of the way - now onto Paralympic tickets.... :-)

We want to create a replica version of the Olympic schedule http://www.london2012.com/games/olympic-sport-competition-schedule/index.php to sit on a separate page. Data will be supplied in a similar format.

With both schedules though, there are a number of upgrades we'd like to make - see the log attached. We would also like to adopt a few of the features from the Telegraph searchable schedule  at http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/olympics/8288662/London-2012-Olympics-competition-schedule.html

The time for this is release in July (though we are announcing Paralympic ticket prices in mid-May). Just want to give you a heads-up so we can review the next steps - may be something we ask a design or usability agency to do some work on as well.

Hi,

The upgrades we'd like to make are in the previously attached 'feedback log' however here they are separately.

Dynamic dropdowns.  Limit choices available in dropdowns based on values already selected, e.g. only show 
Weymouth in venue dropdown if Sailing selected as sport.

Reset button.  Button to clear out all search criteria and display full list of events.

Hyperlinked sports and venues.  Link through to relevant pages on london2012.com.

Darker background colour.  Currently very difficult to see background colour of table and therefore cell delineators. 



Do get in touch if you have any questions,

Thanks

Hi guys - I think Jamie is picking this up.
Just to flag that as this will be launching in August we probably need to raise the priority of this now to get working on it,

Thanks,

Tom

Actually no as this is just a regular URL. But the short URL www.london2012.com/Volunteeringhttp://www.london2012.com/Volunteering should work the same as www.london2012.com/Volunteeringhttp://www.london2012.com/Volunteering and redirect to http://www.london2012.com/get-involved/volunteer/index.php.

Original ticket number 1400.

Regards,
Andy

When we made the amendments to the shorturl interface, it was agreed that /existing/ short urls should be left alone - i.e. should carry on being case-sensitive. I do not have the conversation to-hand but I think/presume it was to ensure that no existing behaviour was impacted.
I can go back through and make all short urls ignore case, however it's not a trivial job, as to do it "properly" means generating a list of them, and testing that they all work pre and post-change.
I don't have an example of what might break if I don't perform this test, however I think it for a change of this magnitude, it would be a sensible precaution.

NB Andy is correct regarding "get-involved" being a "real" folder name, rather than a short-url.
We could - if was acceptable to the SEO consultants - enable mod_speling (sic) which would accept urls in any combination of upper/lower case. My opinion is that this would not impact SEO, as we already set "link rel=canonical" headers. However it's not my call!

Kieran

Andy, what do you think about Kieran’s NB?

Also, Kieran could you please quote the amount of work it would be to retrospectively look at the existing short urls?

My view is that we don’t need to look at existing short URLs (although it would be nice if we could tell if they had the case-insensitive attribute), but we should enable the mod_speling thing, which Mr SEO has funnily enough just asked for this last week. His specific comments as follows:

“I typically deploy the following two rules on every web project that I work on:
1. 301 all requests with no subdomain specified to the www. equivalent of the URL (e.g. a request for london2012.com should 301 to www.london2012.com and a request for london2012.com/sports should 301 to www.london2012.com).
2. 301 all requests with uppercase characters to their lower case equivalent. (e.g. a request for www.london2012.com/Sports would redirect to www.london2012.com/sports) - before implementing this ensure that canonical URL can only be specified with lower case characters.
Simple Apache rules exist to implement this logic. Once the rules are in place a request for london2012.com/Sports would redirect to www.london2012.com/sports.”

Kieran, can you comment on doability?
